[[The Bronx]], [[New York City|New York]], United States | origin = | instrument = [[Piano]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[East Coast blues]], [[rhythm and blues]] | occupation = [[Pianist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1947–1997 | label = Various | associated_acts = | notable_instruments = }} '''Bob Gaddy''' (February 4, 1924 – July 24, 1997) was an [[United States|American]] [[East Coast blues]] and [[rhythm and blues]] [[pianist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. He is best remembered for his recordings of "Operator" and "Rip and Run," and musical work he undertook with [[Larry Dale]], [[Wild Jimmy Spruill]], [[Sonny Terry]] and [[Brownie McGhee]].{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1996.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1996 - 1997 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}} ==Biography== Gaddy was born in [[Vivian, West Virginia]], a small town based around [[coal mining]]. He learned to play the piano at a young age, both playing and singing in his local church. In 1943 he was [[Conscription|conscripted]] and served in the [[United States Navy|Navy]], being stationed in [[California]]. He progressed from learning the [[blues]] and, using his [[gospel music|gospel]] background, graduated towards the [[boogie-woogie]] playing style. He played in blues [[nightclub|clubs]] in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] and [[San Francisco]], but after [[World War II]] finished he relocated to [[New York City|New York]] in 1946. Gaddy later commented "I came to New York just to visit, because I was on my way to the West Coast. Somehow or other, I just got hooked on it. New York got into my system and I've been stuck here ever since." He found work as a blues pianist, and in the late 1940s Gaddy provided accompaniment to both [[Brownie McGhee]] and [[Sonny Terry]]. He later backed [[Larry Dale]], and befriended [[Champion Jack Dupree]]. Dupree penned "Operator" for Gaddy, one of his best selling numbers. Gaddy recorded firstly for Jackson Records with his debut [[single (music)|single]] being "Bicycle Boogie" in 1952. Gaddy later spent time with the Jax, [[Dot Records|Dot]] and Harlem record labels, before joining [[Hy Weiss]]' Old Town Records in 1956. It was here that Gaddy had his most commercially successful period, particularly with "I Love My Baby," "Paper Lady," and "Rip and Run." His earlier recordings often had McGhee in the [[recording studio]] with Gaddy, although his Old Town recordings utilised the [[guitarist]]s [[Wild Jimmy Spruill|Jimmy Spruill]] and Joe Ruffin, plus [[saxophone|saxophonist]] Jimmy Wright. Gaddy ceased his [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] activities around 1960. However, along with his long time friend Larry Dale, Gaddy remained a mainstay of the ongoing New York blues scene.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p173355/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Bob Gaddy|author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=May 22, 2010}} In April 1988, Gaddy, Dale and Spruill reunited to play at the Tramps nightclub in New York.{{cite web|author=Jon Pareles |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1988/04/29/arts/pop-jazz-new-york-rockers-singing-the-blues-loudly-and-clearly.html |title=POP/JAZZ; New York Rockers Singing the Blues Loudly and Clearly - New York Times |location=New York City |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1988-04-29 |accessdate=2014-01-25}} Bob Gaddy died of [[lung cancer]] in [[the Bronx]], New York in July 1997, at the age of 73.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/mojobluesband2 |title=Mojo Blues Band | Blues Parade 2000 | CD Baby Music Store |publisher=Cdbaby.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}} ==Discography== ===Singles=== *"I (Believe You Got A Sidekick)" / "Bicycle Boogie" (1952) -
